head.title: May 21-27; Religion Loses a Round to Women In Israel

hedline.hl1: May 21-27; Religion Loses a Round to Women In Israel

block.p: The Israeli Supreme Court ruled that women can hold group services, wear prayer shawls and read aloud from Torah scrolls at the Western Wall, a part of the Jewish temple complex that was destroyed by the Romans in A.D. 70, and Judaism's most revered shrine.

In keeping with strict Orthodox Jewish tradition, men and women worship at the wall in separate areas divided by a partition, and only the men hold services. The court gave the government six months to arrange for women's services.

The Israeli Supreme Court ruled that women can hold group services, wear prayer shawls and read aloud from Torah scrolls at the Western Wall, a part of the Jewish temple complex that was destroyed by the Romans in A.D. 70, and Judaism's most revered shrine.

In keeping with strict Orthodox Jewish tradition, men and women worship at the wall in separate areas divided by a partition, and only the men hold services. The court gave the government six months to arrange for women's services.
''We've come out of the Middle Ages,'' said Anat Hoffman, a leader of the women's group. ''Today the Western Wall became part of the State of Israel.''

The ruling was condemned by Orthodox officials and rabbis. Deputy Religious Affairs Minister Yigal Bibi, a member of the National Religious Party, said the Supreme Court had issued yet another ruling that would ''nullify the State of Israel as a Jewish state and turn it into a state of all its citizens.''
